Clean and standardize teacher name formatting

Source: R/class_list_functions.R
clean_teacher_names.Rd

Converts all teacher name fields in a class list to title case (e.g., "john SMITH" becomes "John Smith"). This ensures consistent formatting across teacher names for display, reporting, and downstream processing.

Usage

clean_teacher_names(
  data,
  teacher_name_col = "Main Teacher Name",
  TeacherFNColumn = "Main Teacher First Name",
  TeacherLNColumn = "Main Teacher Last Name"
)

Arguments

data

A data frame containing class list information. Must include teacher name columns such as `"Main Teacher Name"`, `"Main Teacher First Name"`, and `"Main Teacher Last Name"`.

teacher_name_col

Character string giving the name of the column containing the teacher's full name. Defaults to `"Main Teacher Name"`.

TeacherFNColumn

Character string giving the name of the column containing the teacher's first name. Defaults to `"Main Teacher First Name"`.

TeacherLNColumn

Character string giving the name of the column containing the teacher's last name. Defaults to `"Main Teacher Last Name"`.

Value

A data frame identical to the input `data`, with all teacher name columns converted to title case.

Details

This function is typically used after data extraction or merging steps to clean up inconsistent capitalization in teacher names. It is complementary to clean_class_names() and reduce_to_best_teacher(), providing the final formatting pass before export.

If any of the specified teacher name columns are missing from the input data, the function will stop with an informative error message.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
cleaned_df <- clean_teacher_names(class_list_df)
head(cleaned_df[, c("Main Teacher Name", "Main Teacher First Name", "Main Teacher Last Name")])
} # }
